_exec_summary.SummaryText:
FUJIFILM Hunt Chemicals U.S.A., Inc. Dayton, TN facility strives to provide a facility that is safe for its employees, the community and the environment.  The Dayton facility is a batch process organic chemical production facility that operates 24 hours a day/ 7days a week.  The facility produces numerous products on three production lines, with a majority of products related to photographic processing.

The chemical regulated by RMP is phosphorus oxy chloride; it will be utilized in a process that is operated approximately 15 days per year.  Each annual campaign utilizes 13,000 lbs. (18 drums) of phosphorus oxy chloride, 13,000 lbs. will be the maximum amount stored on site.  Prior to use, the drums will be stored in the facility warehouse, which is monitored and secured.

The Dayton facility has robust safety, environmental and emergency response programs.   The facility is covered under OSHA?s Process Safety Management standard, which requires it to conduct Process Hazard Assessments that identify hazards and protective measures in a chemical process; mechanical integrity programs to ensure proper equipment maintenance and numerous other requirements.  The facility is also ISO 14001 certified and a member of EPA?s Performance Track, both of which require FUJIFILM to document and conform to environment procedures and conduct internal and receive external audits.

FUJIFILM Dayton has a complete hazmat response team.  All Operators, Maintenance Techs and EHS Techs are trained Hazmat Technicians.  The facility is equipped with portable chemical monitoring, Level A encapsulating chemical suits, numerous types of respiratory protection and clean up and overpacking supplies on site sufficient to contain and clean up a significant amount of material.  In addition, the company maintains contracts with two separate hazmat response companies for back up support.  The facility also communicates regularly with the local fire and law enforcement agencies.

Since 1996, when FUJ

IFILM purchased the facility, there have been no off site chemical releases or any uncontrolled release to the environment.  The facility did have a serious incident and fire in August 2006, no chemicals were released and internal sprinklers extinguished the fire.  One employee was seriously injured and subsequently passed away.  Numerous changes to safety and management systems have been instituted since this incident.
